questions.solution: Ans. C. C

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair?

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic haemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum – infants
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Falciform ligament

questions.text: A 46-year-old man is hospitalized for treatment of a stomach ulcer that has been getting progressively worse over several months. UGIE reveals the site of involvement to be along the greater curvature, approximately 4 cm away from the pyloric sphincter. That night, the ulcer perforates, and there is considerable intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgery reveals that the ulcer has eroded through the stomach wall and has damaged the artery supplying the involved region of the stomach. Which artery was likely involved?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Right gastroepiploic artery

questions.text:
Identify the correct statement

  1. Type I collagen is seen in bone and elastic cartilage
  2. Reticular fibres are present in lymph nodes, bone marrow and thymus
  3. Right-left movement is by atlanto-axial joint
  4. Costo-transverse joints are plane synovial joints
questions.solution: Ans. C. 3,4

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever and a lesion on his right foot. The initial lesion was erythematous and oedematous, but it quickly developed into a bulla surrounded by erythema. Eventually, the bulla ruptured, leaving a painless ulcer with a black centre. The patient has a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and recently underwent chemotherapy. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's foot lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antipseudomonal penicillin

 

Step 1: Diagnosis from Clinical Clues:

 

  • Patient: immunocompromised (non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chemotherapy).
  • Lesion evolution: erythematous → edematous → bulla → ruptured ulcer with black necrotic center.
  • This is classic for Ecthyma gangrenosum, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • These necrotic skin ulcers are strongly associated with bacteremia in neutropenic/chemotherapy patients.

 

Step 2: Treatment:

 

  • Requires antipseudomonal coverage (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, ceftazidime, cefepime, imipenem, meropenem).
  • Therefore, D) Antipseudomonal penicillin is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salvage chemotherapy: Irrelevant here; underlying lymphoma is not the acute problem.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: Would worsen infection by further immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Antistaphylococcal penicillin:

 

  • Covers MSSA (e.g., oxacillin, nafcillin), not Pseudomonas.
  • Wrong choice because the lesion is typical for Pseudomonas, not staph.

questions.solution: Ans. D) CN III, CN VI, and CN XII

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Filiform

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office due to a week of low-grade fever, dry cough, and right-sided chest pain. The pain is intermittent, sharp, and worse with deep inhalation or cough. The patient also notes mild "achiness" in his knees and ankles that started around the same time. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient is an Army officer, and he returned after completing desert training exercises in Rajasthan. He does not know if other participants developed similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100 °F). Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 16/min. Lung auscultation shows right-sided crackles. No joint swelling or tenderness is present, but there are erythematous, tender nodules on the bilateral shins. Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate with a prominent right hilum. Which of the following is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coccidioides immitis

 

  • The patient is an Army officer returning from desert training in Rajasthan → exposure to arid soil endemic fungi.
  • Presents with:
    • Low-grade fever, pleuritic chest pain, dry cough → pulmonary involvement.
    • Arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum on shins → classic hypersensitivity findings.
    • CXR: unilateral lower lobe infiltrate + hilar adenopathy.
  • These features are typical of primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis, caused by Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: 

 

  • Endemic to Mississippi & Ohio River valleys, Great Lakes.
  • Causes pneumonia with skin/bone involvement, not linked to desert regions like Rajasthan.

 

Option C. Histoplasma capsulatum: 

 

  • Endemic to Ohio & Mississippi River valleys.
  • Associated with bat/bird droppings (caves, chicken coops).
  • In India, histoplasmosis is rare and not desert-related.

 

Option D. Legionella pneumophila:

 

  • Causes atypical pneumonia with high fever, diarrhea, hyponatremia.
  • Spread via contaminated water (air conditioning, plumbing), not desert soil.
  • Does not cause erythema nodosum.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A) Balamuthia mandrillaris → Pseudopodia (3)

 

  • A free-living amoeba causing granulomatous amebic encephalitis.
  • Amoebae move using pseudopodia.

 

B) Balantidium coli → Cilia (2)

 

  • The only ciliate protozoan infecting humans.
  • Moves and feeds with cilia.

 

C) Trichomonas vaginalis → Flagella (1)

 

  • Urogenital protozoan parasite.
  • Motility via flagella.

 

D) Toxoplasma gondii → No particular locomotory organ (4)

 

  • An apicomplexan parasite.
  • Has no locomotory organelle; moves via gliding mechanism using apical complex.

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Coxiella burneti

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Sternothyroid

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

The fontanelles are membranous gaps between the skull bones in infants that allow brain growth and facilitate childbirth. Their closure times are clinically important.

 

  • Anterior fontanelle (bregmatic):
    • Largest fontanelle (diamond-shaped).
    • Closes last, usually by 18–24 months of age.
  • Posterior fontanelle (lambdoid/occipital):
    • Small, triangular.
    • Closes by 2–3 months.
  • Mastoid fontanelle:
    • At junction of squamous temporal, parietal, and occipital bones.
    • Closes by 6–18 months.
  • Sphenoidal (anterolateral) fontanelle:
    • At junction of frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones.
    • Closes by 6 months.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks gestation comes to the office for her initial prenatal visit. She has no symptoms except mild nausea. She smoked a pack of cigarettes a day and drank 7-8 beers each week but quit after learning she was pregnant. The patient has a history of an allergic reaction to penicillin; she developed a generalized rash with intense itching that responded to antihistamines and corticosteroid cream. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The screening VDRL test is positive, fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is positive. Her HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin testing and penicillin desensitization

 

  • The patient is pregnant and has confirmed syphilis (VDRL + FTA-ABS positive).
  • The only proven therapy for syphilis in pregnancy is penicillin G, which prevents congenital syphilis.
  • Since she has a history of penicillin allergy, the 
  • If positive → penicillin desensitization, followed by recommended management is:
    1. Skin testing for penicillin allergy, and
    2. treatment with penicillin G.
  • Alternative antibiotics (eg, doxycycline, azithromycin) are not reliable in pregnancy and do not adequately protect the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Azithromycin:

 

  • Has been studied but resistance is common.
  • Not recommended in pregnancy for syphilis.

 

Options B. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy (ADR: tooth discoloration, bone effects).

 

Options C. No treatment until delivery. Detrimental to fetus. Increases risk of congenital syphilis with severe neonatal complications (Triad of stillbirth, Hutchinson’s teeth, saddle nose).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Microscopic agglutination test

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

  • The image shows Sarcoptes scabiei, the mite that causes scabies.
  • Clinical picture: intense nocturnal pruritus, papules/plaques in finger web spaces, groin, inframammary folds → classic scabies.
  • Life cycle facts:
    • Life history has 4 stages: egg → larva → nymph → adult. [option A]
    • Larva has 3 pairs of legs, whereas nymphs/adults have 4 pairs. [option B]
    • Entire life cycle on human skin takes about 10–14 days (≈15 days). [option C]
    • Female mite burrows into the stratum corneum to lay eggs.[option D]
    • Male mite does not burrow; it dies after fertilizing the female on the skin surface.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Levator veli palatini

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is suffering from numbness over the tip of her nose. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Prozone phenomenon

Organize the subsequent afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle, proceeding from the medial to the lateral direction.

2. General visceral

3. Special somatic

4. Special visceral
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2, 4, 1, 3

questions.solution: Ans. C. QuantiFERON gold

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

  1. Stimulation of this area results in turning the eyes and head to the contralateral side
  2. A lesion here results in nonfluent, telegraphic speech
  3. Ablation in this area results in a contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopia
  4. A lesion here results in fluent speech with neologisms
  5. A lesion of this area is characterized by finger agnosia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia, and dyslexia
  6. Destruction of this area results in an aphasia characterized by fluent speech, good com- prehension, and poor repetition
  7. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral astereognosis
  8. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral spasticity
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-H, 2-G, 3-F, 4-E, 5-D, 6-C ,7-B, 8-A

 

The correct matching of numbered clinical findings to the labeled areas on the brain diagram as per the answer and options is:

 

  1. Stimulation of this area results in turning the eyes and head to the contralateral side
     — H. Frontal eye field
  2. A lesion here results in nonfluent, telegraphic speech
     — G. Broca’s area
  3. Ablation in this area results in a contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopia
     — F. Inferior portion of the optic radiation (Meyer’s loop/temporal lobe)
  4. A lesion here results in fluent speech with neologisms
     — E. Wernicke’s area
  5. A lesion of this area is characterized by finger agnosia, dyscalculia, dysgraphia, and dyslexia
     — D. Angular gyrus
  6. Destruction of this area results in an aphasia characterized by fluent speech, good comprehension, and poor repetition
     — C. Arcuate fasciculus
  7. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral astereognosis
     — B. Somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus)
  8. Lesions in this gyrus result in contralateral spasticity
     — A. Precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex)

questions.solution: Ans. A. Enveloped ss RNA

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

 

  1. Main elevator of mandible
  2. Superior head originates from infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing
  3. Receives supply from main trunk of trigeminal nerve
  4. Originates from zygomatic arch and inserts on the angle of mandible
questions.solution: Ans. B. A-1, B-4, C-2, D-3

questions.text: The diameter of the structure in the picture taken from a dead male is 3.1 cm. What is the name of the autosomal recessive trait that this person evidenced?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mounier-Kuhn syndrome

 

The structure in the image is likely a trachea or bronchus. A diameter of 3.1 cm is abnormally dilated. This, in combination with the inheritance pattern (autosomal recessive), is characteristic of Mounier-Kuhn syndrome (tracheobronchomegaly).

 

Mounier-Kuhn syndrome is a rare genetic disorder resulting in marked dilatation of the trachea and main bronchi due to atrophy of elastic and smooth muscle fibers, leading to recurrent respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spontaneous pneumothorax: Associated with ruptured blebs, not airways dilatation. Associated with Marfan disease[Autosomal Dominant].

 

Option B. Asbestosis: Pneumoconiosis with fibrosis, not airway dilatation. Commonly affects basal lobes

 

Option C. Emphysema: Destruction of alveolar walls, can cause bullae but not enlarged trachea/bronchi. It is a part of spectrum of COPD.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Scalp, dura, arachnoid

questions.text: A patient with a deep knife wound in the buttock walks with a waddling gait that is characterized by the pelvis falling toward one side at each step. Which of the following nerves is damaged?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Superior gluteal nerve

What are the derivatives of the marked cells?

 

  1. Odontoblasts

  2. Sympathetic chain

  3. Melanocytes

  4. Nephrogenic cord

  5. Bulbus cordis

  6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 6

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

 

  1. Rupture of the tendon superior to this structure would most likely cause an inability to extend the knee joint.
  2. Fracture of this structure would most likely cause weakness in adduction of the thigh.
  3. A knife penetrating through this point would most likely cause muscle ischemia in the anterior compartment of the leg.
  4. Fracture of this structure would most likely cause impaired dorsiflexion of foot
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

  • 1 → C (patella)
    Rupture of the quadriceps tendon (superior to the patella) → inability to extend the knee.
  • 2 → A (medial femoral condyle/adductor tubercle)
    Fracture here disrupts attachment of the adductor magnus tendon → weak thigh adduction.
  • 3 → B (proximal interosseous gap region)
    A stab here can injure the anterior tibial artery as it passes through the proximal opening in the interosseous membrane → ischemia of the anterior compartment.
  • 4 → E (neck of fibula)
    Fracture at the fibular neck endangers the common fibular nerve → foot drop with impaired dorsiflexion (deep fibular nerve).

choices.text: Flexion and medial rotation

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Extension and lateral rotation

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the office due to a flu like illness with low-grade fever, malaise, nausea, and anorexia. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She occasionally smokes marijuana and has used injection drugs in the past. She has had several sexual partners. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 121/78 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min. The patient has scleral icterus. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows:

Total bilirubin-44.8 mg/dL

Aspartate aminotransferase-11,222 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase-21,184 U/L

Hepatitis B surface antibody - Positive

Hepatitis B core antibody - Positive

Hepatitis B surface antigen - Negative

Hepatitis A IgM antibody - Positive

Hepatitis A lgG antibody - Negative

Hepatitis C antibody - Negative

After discussing the findings, the patient says she is worried that she may transmit the disease to her boyfriend. Which of the following interventions for the boyfriend is most likely to decrease his risk of disease acquisition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A vaccination

 

  • Patient has:
    • AST & ALT extremely elevated (>10,000 U/L) → typical of acute viral hepatitis.
    • Serology:
      • HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc positive → past, resolved hepatitis B infection with immunity.
      • Hepatitis A IgM positive, IgG negative → indicates acute Hepatitis A infection.
  • Transmission: fecal–oral, not sexual like HBV/HIV.
  • Her boyfriend is at risk of acquiring Hepatitis A through close household/sexual contact.
  • Best prevention: administer Hepatitis A vaccine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrier contraceptive use: Reduces risk of STIs (HIV, HBV, gonorrhea, etc.) but not effective for fecal–oral transmission of Hepatitis A.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B immune globulin: Unnecessary. Patient already cleared HBV and is immune (HBsAg negative, anti-HBs positive).

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccination: Also unnecessary; patient does not have active HBV infection, so no risk to her partner.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment star marked in the image below:
questions.solution: Ans. A. V

questions.text: 42-year-old man with advanced HIV has a 2-week history of pain and difficulty swallowing. He was given oral fluconazole for these symptoms a week ago, but his pain has worsened. His current medications include antiretrovirals and trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole. His CD4 count is 40/uL and viral load is 300,000 copies/mL. Endoscopy shows large, irregular, linear ulcers in the distal oesophagus. A biopsy of the abnormal mucosa shows tissue destruction and the presence of intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Ganciclovir

questions.text: Which of the following upper limb muscles is bipennate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dorsal interossei

 

Let's discuss each of the given options :

 

Option A. Palmar interossei: The palmar interossei are intrinsic muscles of the hand located between the metacarpal bones. Their primary function is adduction of the fingers, i.e., bringing the fingers toward the midline (toward the third finger). These muscles are unipennate, meaning their muscle fibers run obliquely from one side to a central tendon.

 

Option B. 1st lumbrical: The lumbricals are four muscles in the hand that have the primary function of flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints. The 1st lumbrical originates from the radial side of the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger. This muscle is not bipennate; instead, it has a simpler structure extending from its origin to its insertion.

 

Option C. 2nd lumbrical: The 2nd lumbrical, like the other lumbricals, assists in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joint and extending the interphalangeal joints. It originates from the radial side of one tendon and the ulnar side of the adjacent tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus. However, despite this dual origin, the muscle itself is not structured in a bipennate manner.

 

Option D. Dorsal interossei: The dorsal interossei are four muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. Their primary function is to abduct the fingers, meaning they move the fingers away from the midline (away from the third finger). Structurally, these muscles are bipennate, having fibers that run from both sides to a central tendon, giving them a feather-like appearance.

questions.text: 19-year-old man comes to the office with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and sore throat. He has no diarrhoea or rash. The patient has no significant medical history. He occasionally uses tobacco and alcohol. The patient is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms occasionally. Temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 16/min. Physical examination shows enlarged tonsils with white exudates. Enlarged, tender, mobile nodes are palpable along the cervical, axillary, and inguinal chains bilaterally. The examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following tests is most likely to yield the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Heterophile antibody test

questions.text: 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 1 day of painful swelling of the left side of her face, associated with high fever and chills. She has had no facial trauma or injury to that area. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 3 years ago and achieves good glycemic control with diet, exercise, and oral hypoglycemic agents; she has no known complications. Temperature is 39.2 C (102.6 F), blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Physical examination shows a warm, tender, erythematous rash with raised, well-demarcated borders on the left side of the face, including the left external ear. The ear canal has no discharge, and hearing is intact. Mild regional lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient's infection?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Group A Streptococcus

questions.text: Which is the method for making the inoculation for antibiotic sensitivity testing shown here?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Lawn culture

questions.text: 26-year-old man comes to the office due to right heel pain and swelling. He accidentally stepped on a rusty nail while working 2 weeks ago. The nail pierced his sneaker and entered his right heel. He applied over-the-counter antibiotic cream and took oral acetaminophen but continued to have pain. The patient has no other medical problems and takes no medications. He has no known drug allergies. He smokes 2 or 3 cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol occasionally. Temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 14/min. The right heel is swollen, red, warm, and tender to palpation. A small puncture wound is visible. Laboratory results show mild leukocytosis. X ray of the right foot reveals bone changes suggestive of osteomyelitis. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing this patient's infection?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text:
Identify the false statements:

  1. Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is diagnostic of Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  2. E6, E7 are targets of vaccine against HPV
  3. SARS CO-2 specimen handling for molecular testing needs BSL-2
  4. Peptostreptococcus causes scromboid fish poisoning
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 4

 

Statement 2. E6, E7 are targets of vaccine against HPV:

 

  • False. HPV vaccines (bivalent, quadrivalent, nonavalent) target the L1 capsid protein, not the oncoproteins E6 and E7.
  • E6 and E7 are virulence factors that inactivate p53 and Rb, but they are not vaccine targets.

 

Statement 4. Peptostreptococcus causes scombroid fish poisoning:

 

  • False. Scombroid poisoning is due to ingestion of histamine formed by bacterial decarboxylation of histidine in spoiled fish such as tuna or mackerel.
  • Caused by Morganella morganii, Klebsiella, Proteus, not Peptostreptococcus.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is diagnostic of Ehrlichia chaffeensis: True. Ehrlichia chaffeensis infects monocytes and macrophages, forming intracytoplasmic inclusions called morulae.

 

Statement 3. SARS-CoV-2 specimen handling for molecular testing needs BSL-2

 

  • True. Routine diagnostic handling of respiratory samples for RT-PCR requires BSL-2 precautions.
  • Virus culture or propagation requires BSL-3.

questions.text:
Match the descriptions in items 1 to 5 with the appropriate lettered lesion in the diagram of a cross-section of the spinal cord.

  1. Ipsilateral lower limb dystaxia
  2. Ipsilateral flaccid paralysis
  3. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation one segment below the lesion
  4. Exaggerated muscle stretch reflexes below the lesion
  5. Loss of two-point tactile discrimination in the ipsilateral foot
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-E, 4-C, 5-A

 

Here are the correct matches for the spinal cord cross-section lesions:

 

  1. Ipsilateral lower limb dystaxia
     B (Lateral/Posterior Cerebellar Tract—dorsal spinocerebellar tract)
  2. Ipsilateral flaccid paralysis
     D (Anterior Horn—lower motor neuron lesion)
  3. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation one segment below the lesion
     E (Spinothalamic Tract—crosses over within 1-2 segments)
  4. Exaggerated muscle stretch reflexes below the lesion
     C (Corticospinal Tract—upper motor neuron lesion)
  5. Loss of two-point tactile discrimination in the ipsilateral foot
     A (Posterior Columns—gracile fasciculus)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake 15 days back. Urine microscopy is shown. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Schistosoma hematobium

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with severe head injuries after a car crash. During neurologic examination her uvula is found to be deviated to the right. Which nerve is most likely affected to result in this deviation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left vagus

 

A lesion of the left vagus nerve will cause the uvula to deviate to the right. The muscles of the soft palate innervated by the vagus nerve elevate the palate; if one side (left) is paralyzed, the palate is pulled up by the healthy side (right), causing the uvula to deviate toward the right.

 

Rule of 17:

 

  • 10 and 7 cause contralateral deviation-{10 and contra both have o in them, if one is 10 other should be 7 = nmemonic}
  • 5 and 12 cause ipsilateral deviation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right vagus: A lesion of the right vagus would cause the uvula to deviate to the left (toward the healthy side), not the right.

 

Option C. Left glossopharyngeal: Glossopharyngeal nerve lesions affect sensation to the posterior third of the tongue and oropharynx, but do not cause uvular deviation.

 

Option D. Right glossopharyngeal: Similar to the left, would affect taste/sensation, but would not result in uvular deviation.

questions.text: A 5-day-old female infant was born with a facial defect. The greater cornuae and the inferior part of the hyoid bone were absent at birth. Failure of development of which of the following embryonic structures most likely led to these defects?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 3rd pharyngeal arch

questions.text: A farmer from Uttarakhand had a thorn prick injury and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination.  Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Chromoblastomycosis

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the clinic with fever, exertional dyspnoea, and non productive cough for one week. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 3 years ago but has been asymptomatic since. He has not been taking his medications consistently. His temperature is 38.9 C (102 °F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 28/min. The patient's pulse oximetry shows 80% on room air. With use of a 100% nonrebreather mask, his oxygen saturation increases to 92%.

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin - 9.6 g/dL

 

Platelets - 120,000/mm³

 

Leukocytes - 8,000/mm³ (no bands)

 

Arterial blood gases on room air

 

pH - 7.45

 

PaO₂ - 54 mm Hg

 

PaCO₂ - 44 mm Hg

 

Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. His CD4 count is 190/mm³ and lactate dehydrogenase level is 400 U/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids

 

  • HIV patient with CD4 <200 and subacute fever, exertional dyspnea, dry cough plus diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates → classic for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP).
  • Lab findings: hypoxemia (PaO₂ = 54 mm Hg), elevated LDH → typical in PCP.
  • Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the drug of choice.
  • Adjunctive corticosteroids are indicated when there is significant hypoxemia:
    • PaO₂ <70 mm Hg on room air or
    • Alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient ≥35 mm Hg.
  • This patient qualifies → needs TMP-SMX plus corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiation of antiretroviral treatment: ART is essential but not started in acute PCP with severe illness until infection is stabilized, to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).

 

Option B. Intravenous pentamidine and corticosteroids: Pentamidine is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate TMP-SMX. TMP-SMX is first-line.

 

Option D. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Correct drug, but corticosteroids must also be added here due to severe hypoxemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?

  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers
questions.solution: Ans. C. 1, 2, 4

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office for evaluation of "itchy private parts" for the past week. Her mother has noticed the scratching at bedtime but not during the day. Due to the itching, the patient has difficulty falling asleep. Her mother has been applying a topical emollient with only minimal symptom relief. The patient has no urinary symptoms and has soft bowel movements once every other day. She attends day-care during the week and lives with her mother, father, and 13-year-old brother, none of whom have similar symptoms. Physical examination shows an erythematous vulva and no vaginal discharge. The perianal area is excoriated and diffusely erythematous. No other lesions are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Helminth infection

questions.text: A patient presented with paradoxical respiration. Which of the following structures is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution: Ans. C. C

choices.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days
Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores?

 

1. Glutaraldehyde

2. Ethylene oxide

3. Pasteurization

4. Orthophthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

  • Statement 1. Glutaraldehyde (2%): High-level disinfectant, can achieve sterilization and kill spores if items are immersed long enough (≥10 hours).
  • Statement 2. Ethylene oxide: Gas sterilization method, penetrates well and kills spores; used for heat/moisture-sensitive instruments.
  • Statement  4. Orthophthalaldehyde (OPA): High-level disinfectant, similar to glutaraldehyde, and effective against spores with prolonged exposure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

  • Statement  3. Pasteurization: Only kills vegetative bacteria and some viruses; does not kill spores (reason milk is not sterile after pasteurization).

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1

choices.text: Median nerve
Radial nerve
Musculocutaneous nerve
Ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which is the nerve most likely to be injured?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

  • Xenodiagnosis = diagnostic method where a live vector/insect is used to detect the pathogen by allowing it to feed on, or be inoculated with, patient material.
  • In dengue, suspected patient’s blood can be injected into the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes, then the mosquito is later tested for viral growth.
  • This is a classic example of a xenodiagnostic method in arboviruses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for ETEC: Pathogenicity test for enterotoxin production, not xenodiagnosis.

 

Option C. Injecting hamster with splenic biopsy for leishmaniasis: This is an animal inoculation method, but not strictly xenodiagnosis (since no vector is involved). Traditionally, xenodiagnosis for leishmaniasis uses sandflies, not hamsters.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for diphtheria toxigenicity: In vivo test for toxin activity, not xenodiagnosis.

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: The false statement about fetal circulation is:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

questions.text: The hormone produced and released by the cell at the tip of the arrow binds to receptors on the surface of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoclast

 

The cell at the tip of the arrow is a parathyroid chief cell, which produces parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH ultimately acts to increase blood calcium by stimulating osteoclasts—cells responsible for bone resorption.

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) binds to receptors (via the RANK/RANKL pathway, indirectly mediated by osteoblasts) that activate osteoclasts, leading to increased bone resorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoblasts: Osteoblasts possess PTH receptors. PTH binding induces them to express RANKL, stimulating osteoclast differentiation. They do not resorb bone directly; they build bone matrix.

 

Option B. Chondrocytes: Chondrocytes are cartilage cells involved in cartilage formation/growth. 

 

Option C. Osteocytes: Osteocytes are mature bone cells embedded in bone matrix, functioning in bone maintenance and mineral homeostasis. They do not express PTH receptors for bone resorption.

choices.text: Dorsal scapular nerve
From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: The muscle marked by the arrow in the image below is innervated by the:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

questions.text:
β 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?

  1. Candidiasis
  2. Aspergillosis
  3. Pneumocystis pneumonia
  4. Mucormycosis
  5. Cryptococcus
  6. Blastomyces
questions.solution: Ans. B. 4,5,6

questions.text: Identify the organism from the life cycle:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Fasciola hepatica

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope?
questions.solution: Ans. D. D

questions.text: During surgery on a 56-year-old man for a squamous cell carcinoma of the neck, the surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Costocervical trunk

Extension
Adduction

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Flexion

questions.text: What is the method for sterilisation of the equipment used to perform the procedure here:
questions.solution: Ans. A. 2% Glutaraldehyde

questions.text: A woman receives an injection of a radio- isotope to determine regional blood flow in the brain. She has a positron emission tomography scan to visualize variations in cortical blood flow. The examiner asks her to think about flexing her index finger without actually doing it. In which of the following cortical areas would you expect to see increased blood flow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supplementary motor cortex

 

When a person is asked to think about movement (motor imagery), but not actually perform it:

 

  • The supplementary motor area (SMA), located on the medial surface of the frontal lobe (anterior to primary motor cortex), shows increased activity.
  • SMA is involved in planning, programming, and initiation of voluntary movements, especially when imagining or preparing to move.
  • In contrast, the primary motor cortex (motor strip) is activated during actual execution of the movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angular gyrus:

 

  • Located in the parietal lobe.
  • Involved in language, number processing, and spatial cognition.
  • Not related to motor planning.

 

Option B. Motor strip (Primary motor cortex, M1):

 

  • Controls execution of voluntary movement.
  • Would be activated if she actually flexed her finger, not just thought about it.

 

Option C. S-I somatosensory cortex:

 

  • Processes tactile and proprioceptive input.
  • Not directly involved in planning or imagining movement.

questions.text: Red pigment is formed by all except:
questions.solution: Ans. D. Pseudomonas

questions.text: A lady from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer surrounded by erythema on the right leg. Microscopy of the biopsy from the edge of the ulcer showed organisms with dark staining nuclei and kinetoplast. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Leishmania tropica

choices.text: Right lobe of liver
Quadrate lobe of liver
Caudate lobe of liver
Fundus of gallbladder

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Caudate lobe of liver

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Influenza virus

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.text:
6-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery. He was born at 39 weeks’ gestation via spontaneous vagina delivery to a 33-year-old primigravida. The pregnancy was complicated by intravenous drug use. First trimester serologies, including RPR, HIV antibodies, and hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), were negative. Due to the mother's risk profile, follow up testing was obtained during the third trimester and revealed the following lab values: 

 

HBSAg - Positive

Anti-HBsAg - Negative

IgM Anti-HBcAg - Negative

Anti-HBcAg - Positive

Anti HCV - Negative

Liver function testing was normal. The remainder of the

pregnancy was uncomplicated. The infant weighs 3.7 kg (8 lb 3 oz). Physical examination of the infant is normal. There is no jaundice or hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

 

  • Mother’s serology:
    • HBsAg-positive → she is infectious.
    • Anti-HBs negative → no protective immunity.
    • Anti-HBc IgM negative, Anti-HBc positive → indicates chronic carrier state, not acute infection.
    • Infant of an HBsAg-positive mother must receive:
    • Hepatitis B vaccine (active immunization)
    • Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG, passive immunization)
  • Both should be given within 12 hours of birth at different injection sites → provides the best protection against vertical transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin: Incomplete. HBIG alone is not sufficient → baby still needs active immunity.

 

Option C. Administer hepatitis B vaccine: Incomplete. Vaccine alone provides delayed protection; baby needs immediate protection via HBIG.

 

Option D. Obtain hepatitis B antibody panel: Not necessary now. The diagnosis in the mother is clear; newborn must receive post-exposure prophylaxis immediately, not wait for testing.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with rupture of the penile urethra. Extravasated urine from this injury can spread into which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Scrotum

choices.text: Vidian canal

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution: Ans. A) 1, 2

questions.text: Identify the organism from the life cycle:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Strongyloides stercoralis

questions.text: 44-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of a "mole." He has a slowly enlarging macule that was first noticed by his partner 6 weeks ago. The lesion has no associated pain or itching, but it has changed in colour from pink to violet. On review of systems, he denies fever, night sweats, or urinary symptoms. The patient reports an unintentional weight loss of approximately 8 kg over the past year. He was treated for syphilis 2 years ago with long-acting penicillin. He had multiple male sexual partners in the last 20 years and works as a freelance website developer. He does not use tobacco or illicit drugs but drinks alcohol heavily on weekends. Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 14/min. The skin lesion is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's skin lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green

questions.text: A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a painless, non-itchy rash that began this morning. The boy had a fever over the past 3 days, but it resolved on its own today. He takes no medications and his vaccinations are up to date. Examination shows a well-appearing infant with blanching, pink macules on his neck, back, abdomen, and chest. No vesicles are present. The rest of his examination is normal. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human herpesvirus 6

 

  • The child had high fever for 3 days, which suddenly resolved, followed by appearance of a blanching, pink maculopapular rash starting on the trunk and neck.
  • This is classic for Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum, sixth disease), caused by HHV-6 (sometimes HHV-7).
  • Age group: typically infants 6–18 months.
  • The child appears well despite rash, which is another key clue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxsackievirus A:

 

  • Causes hand-foot-mouth disease.
  • Painful oral ulcers + vesicular rash on palms/soles, not trunk-only maculopapular rash.

 

Option C. Measles virus:

 

  • Causes fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, followed by cephalocaudal maculopapular rash.
  • Rash is not limited to trunk and doesn’t appear after fever subsides.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: 

 

  • Causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Classic “slapped-cheek” rash with lacy reticular rash on extremities, not trunk-first rash.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it?
questions.solution: Ans. A. 17D

questions.text: The following result can be attributed to the presence of:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Mycolic acid

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?

  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

choices.text: Vaccinating pigs is helpful in disease control

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Man acts as the reservoir

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman has a history of infection in her perineal region. A comprehensive examination reveals a tear of the superior boundary of the superficial perineal space. Which of the following structures would most likely be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perineal membrane

 

The superficial perineal space (pouch) is a potential space in the urogenital triangle.

 

  • Boundaries:
    • Superior (roof): Perineal membrane (a tough fascial sheet).
    • Inferior (floor): Colles’ fascia (superficial perineal fascia).
    • Laterally: Ischiopubic rami.

 

Therefore, if the superior boundary is torn, the injured structure is the perineal membrane.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic diaphragm:

 

  • Located much deeper (levator ani + coccygeus).
  • Forms the floor of the pelvic cavity, not a boundary of superficial perineal pouch.

 

Option B. Colles fascia:

 

  • Inferior boundary (floor) of superficial perineal pouch.

 

Option C. Deep perineal fascia:

 

  • Covers superficial perineal muscles (e.g., ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus).
  • Not the boundary of the space.

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Frenkel test – Hydatid cyst

questions.text: During a partial hysterectomy leaving the ovaries in tact, the surgeon detaches the ovary from the uterus by transecting the ovarian ligament. This ligament developed from which embryonic structure?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Gubernaculum

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department with back pain, weakness, and shortness of breath. On examination, he has an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta at the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm. Which of the following pairs of structures would most likely be compressed?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Azygos vein and thoracic duct

choices.text: Tdap, intramuscular influenza, and PCV13 vaccines
Tdap, intramuscular influenza, and PPSV23 vaccines

questions.text: 54-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up visit. The patient's medical history includes type 2 diabetes treated with insulin and well-controlled hypertension treated with amlodipine and lisinopril. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He feels well and plans to travel to Goa with his grandchildren for winter break in 1 week. The patient received a flu vaccine a year ago and a tetanus-diphtheria toxoid booster vaccine following an injury 12 years ago; he does not recall his previous vaccination history. Which of the following vaccinations should this patient receive at this visit?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Tdap, intramuscular influenza, and PPSV23 vaccines

questions.text: The hepatic sinusoids that can be observed histologically in an adult liver are derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitelline veins

 

  • The vitelline veins are paired embryonic veins that return blood from the yolk sac to the sinus venosus.
  • During development, they undergo extensive remodeling around the developing hepatic cords.
  • This remodeling gives rise to:
    • Hepatic sinusoids
    • Hepatic segment of inferior vena cava (IVC)
    • Portal vein and its tributaries
    • Part of hepatic veins

 

Thus, the hepatic sinusoids in the adult liver are derived from the vitelline veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supracardinal veins:

 

  • Contribute to the azygos and hemiazygos venous system.
  • Not related to hepatic sinusoids.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal veins:

 

  • Form the internal jugular veins and contribute to the superior vena cava.
  • Not involved in liver development.

 

Option D. Subcardinal veins:

 

  • Contribute to the renal veins, gonadal veins, and suprarenal veins, as well as part of the IVC.
  • Not the source of hepatic sinusoids.

questions.text: A male newborn has a hemangioma on the left frontotemporal region of his face and scalp. The cells forming the hemangioma are derived from which of the following cell layers?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Mesoderm only

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Cytomegalovirus

choices.text: Administer varicella vaccine and varicella immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 5- year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents after exposure to a child with a rash. Three days ago, the patient had a day-long playdate with a friend who had low-grade fever and a vesicular rash. That child and another child in the neighbourhood were subsequently diagnosed with chickenpox. The patient has no symptoms and no history of medical problems. The boy received age-appropriate vaccinations in infancy but has not received any immunizations after age 1.  The boy's mother is currently pregnant and immune to the varicella zoster virus. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the skin, ears, and mucous membranes is normal; the remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Administer varicella vaccine

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office due to right hand pain and swelling. He injured the skin over his right knuckles when he punched a man in the teeth during a bar fight 3 days ago. The patient ignored the wound initially, but his hand became more painful and swollen yesterday. The patient received a tetanus toxoid vaccination at age 18. Temperature is 37.3 C (99.1 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 78/min. There are small lacerations over the right third and fourth metacarpophalangeal joints with surrounding erythema swelling and tenderness. No discharge or crepitus is present. Hand radiographs reveal no foreign body. Which of the following empiric antibiotics is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Amoxicillin-clavulanate

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with severe vomiting, diarrhoea, and dizziness that started this morning. Three days ago, she had nasal bleeding that required anterior packing in the emergency department. Yesterday, she had pain and a sensation of pressure under her left eye and scant blood-tinged nasal discharge. The pain was relieved by acetaminophen and ibuprofen. The patient has a history of asthma and allergic rhinitis. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or ilicit drugs. Her temperature is 38.9° C (102.2° F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg supine and 66/45 mm Hg standing, pulse is 120/min and respirations are 23/min. She appears alert but restless. On examination, there are diffuse, confluent erythematous macules on her trunk and extremities. The oropharynx appears hyperaemic.

Laboratory results are as follows:

Platelets-55,000/uL

Leukocytes-9,500 cells/uL

Bands-30%

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Toxic-shock-syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following structures is present in the male urethra but is not present in the female urethra?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Pseudostratified columnar
